alert.note: Alert for Beaverhead; Blaine; Broadwater; Cascade; Chouteau; Fergus; Gallatin; Glacier; Hill; Jefferson; Judith Basin; Lewis and Clark; Liberty; Madison; Meagher; Pondera; Teton; Toole (Montana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 08 at 10:27AM MDT by NWS GreatFalls
info.description: …POTENTIAL FOR MINOR FLOODING FROM MELTING SNOWPACK EARLY NEXT WEEK… Significant warming of temperatures through early next week will result in some melting of the snowpack, which may increase the risk of flooding for low lying areas and areas with poor drainage. Temperatures on Saturday will once again climb into the 50s at most low to mid elevation locations. This will aid in priming the snowpack to begin melting. Daytime temperatures on Sunday and Monday are then forecast to climb into the upper 50s to 60s for the mid elevations to near 80 degrees for the valleys and plains, which may result in rapid snowmelt runoff. Note that overnight lows Saturday night, and especially on Sunday and Monday nights, will largely remain above freezing. Areas below 4000 ft in elevation will likely have lows above freezing on Saturday night, with above freezing low temperatures expected as high as 6500 to 7500 ft in elevation on both Sunday night and Monday night. The above freezing temperatures during the overnight hours will prolong the period of snow melt and subsequent runoff. Although temperatures are trending warmer this weekend and into early next week, subsurface soil temperatures will still be below freezing, which could exacerbate flooding in low lying areas where the soil is saturated and or frozen. Temperatures will trend cooler again toward mid week next week, but flooding concerns will continue through Tuesday before a cold front moves through. While flooding is not imminent, now is the time to prepare for potential flooding for early next week. Clear ice and debris from culverts and other flow paths to allow runoff to flow away from buildings and other vulnerable infrastructure. Check the functionality of sump pumps prior to the start of runoff to ensure proper operation and prevent basement flooding due to high groundwater levels. Move equipment, forage, and livestock out of poorly drained or low lying areas.
